item.title: Do You Build Wide Area Networks?
item.description: Imagine offering your clients network installations that stretch across the city or even the entire country! You might think it’s impossible, but it’s more achievable than you think. You won’t need massive spools of wire or heavy equipment. Everything is taken care of, allowing you to focus on expanding your business and profits. This is possible due to two key advancements: the rise of Metro and Carrier Ethernet services from competitive carriers and a business model that lets you integrate these Ethernet WAN services into your network designs.

item.title: Buy Convergence By The Byte
item.description: XO Communications is revolutionizing telecommunications by offering IP Network services priced by bandwidth usage instead of traditional lines or channels. This shift to an IP-based network and the use of Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) for telephone trunking are rendering traditional telephony services obsolete. By utilizing a packet-switched network and transmitting everything in packet protocol, voice, and data traffic can easily share a single circuit. The concept of convergence, using one network for voice, video, and data, has gained traction with IT departments aiming to simplify network management and executives seeking cost reductions.

item.title: Contract Expiration Means Opportunity
item.description: Business telecom services often come with fixed-price contracts lasting 1 to 3 years, providing price stability but limited cost-saving opportunities. However, the fear of potential price increases upon contract renewal is often overstated. In many cases, businesses can find better deals by exploring alternative providers. The misconception about limited options arises from a perceived lack of competition. While you may have negotiated what seemed like the best price at the time, there are often numerous competitive service providers not listed in traditional directories.

item.title: MegaPath Duet Combines Voice and Data
item.description: Small and mid-sized businesses need both phone and internet services. Their phone systems often start small and expand over time, adding lines as needed. Similarly, internet service might begin with dial-up, transition to DSL, and eventually upgrade to dedicated connections for better reliability. This piecemeal approach often leads to businesses overspending on telecommunications. Optimizing these systems could potentially cut costs by up to 50%. The key to saving money is bundling services.

item.title: Colocation Hosting Bandwidth Options
item.description: To find the most cost-effective bandwidth, look no further than telecommunication carriers. Bandwidth costs increase as you move away from a carrier’s Point of Presence (POP). The solution: get closer to the carrier. While physically moving in with a carrier might not be feasible, businesses can achieve proximity by utilizing colocation centers, also known as carrier hotels. These facilities, often run by third parties, provide a secure and controlled environment where businesses can house their servers close to multiple carriers.

item.title: Telnes Broadband for T1 Dedicated Internet
item.description: Reliable, always-on internet connectivity has transitioned from a convenient business tool to a necessity. Companies of all types rely on consistent bandwidth for communication with customers, suppliers, and even phone services. Dedicated connections, like T1 data lines, offer the highest reliability with guaranteed uptime. Telnes Broadband is an Internet Service Provider (ISP) catering specifically to businesses and government entities, constituting over 99% of their clientele. Their reputation for dependable WAN connections, especially for businesses with multiple locations, has made them a popular choice.

item.title: T1 PRI is More Than Caller ID
item.description: T1 lines are the most common way to link PBX phone systems to the telephone network. T1 PRI service is often the preferred choice because it can transmit Caller ID information to business phones or call centers. However, there are additional ways that T1 PRI can offer the most budget-friendly phone line trunking. T1 PRI is a highly specialized telecom service. T1 lines have been in use for over half a century to carry phone calls, and more recently, for point-to-point data, dedicated internet service, and connections to private networks.

item.description: Over the past year, major telecom companies have been upgrading their core networks from 40 Gbps to 100 Gbps. Comcast recently joined this trend by incorporating Ciena’s Wave Logic 3 interfaces into their existing Ciena 6500 packet optical platforms. This begs the question: why would a cable company make this change, and how can it benefit your business? Comcast is widely recognized as a Cable TV provider, or MSO (Multi-System Operator).

item.title: Increase Your Bandwidth Beyond T1
item.description: By: John Shepler Your trusty T1 line has served you well for years, maybe even decades. You appreciate its reliability, consistent bandwidth, minimal lag, and decreasing contract prices. However, the bandwidth is becoming a constraint. While 1.5 Mbps was sufficient a decade ago, it’s no longer enough. Can you maintain T1’s performance with faster speeds? Absolutely! What Makes a Good T1 Replacement You had good reasons for choosing T1 when you signed your first contract.

item.title: Internet and Ethernet, The Perfect Broadband Match
item.description: By John Shepler There are many types of broadband internet connections, including DSL, cellular, wireless, cable, satellite, and various fiber optic options. Each has pros and cons regarding cost and performance. However, one technology stands out as the best fit for most businesses: the combination of internet and Ethernet. Why Ethernet? Ethernet’s dominance in wired networks, both big and small, is its biggest strength. It’s the standard protocol for Local Area Networks (LANs), making it compatible with almost all network equipment.

item.title: T1 Line as an On Ramp
item.description: You might know about T1 lines as dedicated connections for digital data or PBX phone lines, but they also serve as excellent access points for various other services. Let’s explore why. Most businesses maintain a Local Area Network (LAN) and a Wide Area Network (WAN) to connect with the wider world. Your WAN connection often acts as an entry point to larger public or private networks. A prime example is “T1 dedicated Internet.

item.title: Goodbye Frame Relay, Hello MPLS
item.description: Managing communication across multiple business locations can be challenging. While private lines offer a solution, their cost increases with the number of locations. Frame Relay, a private network solution, gained popularity for its reliability, security, and affordability. However, MPLS networks have emerged as a newer technology offering higher bandwidth and lower costs. Frame Relay bridges the gap between public switched telephone networks and dedicated private lines. It replaces physical wires with virtual circuits, eliminating the need for dedicated circuits that incur costs regardless of usage.

item.title: Iomega Zips Into Network Storage
item.description: Do you recall the Zip drive? When floppy disks were the standard for backups, Zip drives offered a remarkable hundredfold increase in capacity using removable cartridges. While hard drives now boast hundreds of gigabytes and beyond, leaving floppies and even Zip disks in the past, Iomega, the company behind the Zip drive, has continued to innovate. Their product line has expanded beyond desktops and into the server room. Iomega, now a part of EMC, a Fortune 500 company specializing in enterprise storage solutions, still caters to individuals and small offices.

item.title: Ethernet Better Than a T3 Line
item.description: By: John Shepler T3 voice and data lines, once a reliable option for businesses, now offer insufficient speed (45 Mbps) for modern demands, which often exceed 100 Mbps. Businesses today require significantly faster connections, with some even seeking speeds beyond 10 Gbps. If you’re still using a T3 line, you might find better bandwidth options at a similar or lower cost. What is a T3 Line? Developed by Bell Labs, the T3 line was designed to carry numerous simultaneous phone conversations, a function it still serves in certain settings.

item.title: T1 Lines For MPLS Access
item.description: Companies needing to link numerous locations are increasingly choosing MPLS networks, often finding T1 lines to be the optimal solution for network access. Let’s explore why. Consider an MPLS (Multi Protocol Label Switching) network as a private internet. This private ownership allows the MPLS operator to guarantee the bandwidth and service quality needed for your applications’ reliable operation. Security is also strengthened as access is exclusive to subscribing businesses. An MPLS network functions as a customized cloud, connecting only your specified locations.

item.title: Lower Cost Last Mile Fiber
item.description: By: John Shepler The Internet’s Most Critical Part: Your Last Mile Connection For internet users like you, especially businesses, the most crucial aspect is the “last mile” connection. This final leg of the network often determines speed and causes the most issues. A better connection is essential, and fiber optic technology is the current gold standard. Last Mile Limitations: Why Fiber Matters It’s important to remember that no internet connection is foolproof.

item.title: 10 Gbps Dedicated Internet Access Has the Speed You Need
item.description: By John Shepler Gigabit internet speed is like the gold standard for high-speed business connections. But sometimes even 1 Gbps isn’t enough, and that’s when you need to consider upgrading to 10 Gigabit Internet. Who Needs 10 Gbps Bandwidth? Most small businesses and almost all residential internet users don’t need this much speed. The bragging rights aren’t worth the high monthly fees. This level of bandwidth is meant for demanding applications that justify the cost.

item.title: So Many Locations, So Little Budget
item.description: By: John Shepler Connecting multiple business locations has traditionally been expensive and IT-heavy, often leading companies to settle for less than ideal setups. However, this doesn’t have to be the case anymore. Traditional Business Connections - Why So Pricey? Dedicated private lines, like T1 or SONET fiber lines, were the standard solution. However, they are costly, with prices increasing for each additional site and rural locations. Managing a network of these lines across multiple sites requires routers and specialized systems, adding to the expense and complexity.

item.title: You Mean There's Ethernet in My Building?
item.description: Frustrated with your business broadband and ready to take drastic measures? Before you do, let’s explore reliable and affordable dedicated Internet options. The issue likely isn’t your internal network; it’s the unreliable connection to the broader Internet. While the Internet itself is robust, your chosen connection method might be the problem. DSL or Cable Modem services, while offering substantial bandwidth at low costs for residential users, often lack guaranteed bandwidth allocation.

item.title: What Can GigE Bandwidth Do For You?
item.description: Gigabit Ethernet is becoming increasingly common in local area networks, with network cards and backbones now supporting these higher speeds. Companies that rely heavily on digital processes and high bandwidth data transfers are likely already using Gigabit Ethernet. However, they need a way to extend these high-speed transfers beyond their local networks. Companies with large numbers of employees, extensive customer bases, or applications that generate significant amounts of data can benefit from Gigabit Ethernet WAN connections.

item.title: Tricks That T1 Lines Do
item.description: Many people associate T1 lines with dedicated broadband internet connections, but they offer various business-enhancing applications beyond that. While T1 lines are widely recognized for providing businesses with reliable, dedicated internet connectivity, outperforming consumer-grade options like DSL and cable, their capabilities extend further. T1 connections are governed by regulations, ensuring prioritized support in case of issues and often come with service level agreements for guaranteed performance. item.title: Tips To Reduce Your Telecom Costs
item.description: By: John Shepler Businesses are facing a challenging time as they grapple with the fluctuating economic landscape brought on by the Covid-19 crisis. While growth was once the primary focus, survival has now taken center stage, making cost control paramount. Let’s explore some immediate steps you can take to reduce expenses without jeopardizing operations. Are You Paying For Unused Services? It might seem improbable, but both individuals and businesses frequently pay for services they don’t utilize.

item.title: First in Windmills, First in WiMAX
item.description: To understand the future of technology in the 21st century, one might look to the Netherlands. The Dutch have consistently been at the forefront of business and technology, and now they’re the first in Europe to launch mobile WiMAX as a wireless broadband standard. Mobile WiMAX, based on the IEEE 802.16e standard, expands on the fixed wireless 802.16d standard. It’s being promoted as a large-scale Wi-Fi solution or a remedy for 3G cellular backhaul issues.
